thread.title: Rangers' King gives crown to Canadiens' Carey Price
thread.title_full: Rangers' King gives crown to Canadiens' Carey Price

title: Rangers' King gives crown to Canadiens' Carey Price
text:
Rangers' King gives crown to Canadiens' Carey Price October 15, 2015 Last updated: Thursday, October 15, 2015, 1:21 AM By ANDREW GROSS 
MONTREAL – The way Henrik Lundqvist figures it, the best goalie in the NHL will be on the ice tonight at the Bell Centre when the Canadiens host the Rangers in their home opener. 
And it’s not him. 
For now, the Rangers’ franchise goalie is ceding that crown to Carey Price. 
"I did start thinking about it today that we’re playing Montreal, a good team, and Carey, especially," Lundqvist told The Record after Wednesday’s practice at the Madison Square Garden Training Center in Greenburgh, N.Y. "The way he’s playing right now, he’s probably the best goalie." 
Price, 28, has the hardware to back up Lundqvist’s compliment after garnering four major postseason awards after he went 44-16-6 with a 1.96 goals-against average in 2014-15. 
Price won the Hart Trophy (MVP), Vezina Trophy (top goalie), the Ted Lindsay Award (most outstanding player as voted upon by his fellow players) while sharing the William Jennings Trophy (fewest number of goals allowed). 
"When you’re talking about a top player, goalie or skater, it’s tough to pick one," said Lundqvist, who won the Vezina in 2012 and has been a finalist five times. "But the way he was playing last year, he’s the guy. 
"I think he’s very composed, very technical," Lundqvist added. "I think about two years ago, he raised his game to another level. He was always good but now he’s taken it to another level." 
Price’s stellar play has continued into the start of this season as he’s won his first three starts with a 1.67 GAA for the Canadiens, who swept their season-opening, four-game road trip. In 17 career starts against the Rangers, Price is 10-5-1 with a 1.86 GAA. 
Lundqvist, 33, who will make his fifth straight start and is 3-1-0 with a 2.26 GAA after Tuesday’s 4-1 loss to the visiting Jets, is 14-13-2 lifetime against the Canadiens with a 2.70 GAA. 
The Rangers did beat the Canadiens in six games in the 2014 Eastern Conference final, though Price was injured in Game 1 in a collision with Chris Kreider. 
Lundqvist knows tonight’s game is not about him versus Price. But that showdown aspect is still there. 
"You always want to challenge yourself," Lundqvist said. "He’s definitely one to try to make a game with right now." 
BRIEFS: Emerson Etem, acquired in the offseason from the Ducks for speedy left wing Carl Hagelin, appears poised to make his Rangers’ debut after being a healthy scratch to start the season, though coach Alain Vigneault would not confirm his fourth-line configuration. It’s likely Etem and right wing Jesper Fast, a healthy scratch the past two games, will dress with Jarret Stoll a healthy scratch. … Defenseman Dan Boyle will re-enter the lineup — and the first power-play unit — after being a healthy scratch for the first time since Nov. 11, 2008. "I wouldn’t say it was a shock," said Boyle, who has one assist in three games, of his benching. "It’s only been three games but I haven’t played well."
